SENT.plain: We previously posited that impaired washout of emboli was an important mechanism of brain infarction in patients with cerebral hypoperfusion
Hyperviscosity and hypoperfusion enhance thrombus formation promoting embolization of fresh thrombi
Hypoperfusion also reduces dissolution of emboli due to reduced flow velocity leading to classic hemodynamic patterns of stroke
To prove this concept further, we identified patients with severe hemodynamic compromise of either arterial or venous origin, or both, and natural or iatrogenic mechanisms of embolism

Three conditions were investigated in a stroke MRI protocol: 5 patients who had conventional cerebral angiography for the diagnosis of moyamoya disease, 1 patient with atrial fibrillation and thrombosis of the left transverse dural sinus and 1 patient with a patent foramen ovale with atrial septum aneurysm presenting with thrombosis of cortical cerebral veins
In all patients, subcortical arterial embolization within an atypical borderzone of hypoperfusion was observed
